channel.title: Spring JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [AMQP-328] CachingConnectionFactory.CachedChannelInvocationHandler channels prematurely closed due to channel cache size comparison being off by 1
item.description:
In org.springframework.amqp.rabbit.connection.CachingConnectionFactory.CachedChannelInvocationHandler, channels may be physically closed if the cached channel list exceeds the specified channel cache size. However, the comparison being done to check this is off by one:

if (!RabbitUtils.isPhysicalCloseRequired() && this.channelList.size() < getChannelCacheSize())

{...}

Note that if a user specifies their channel cache size to be 10 because they plan to have 10 consumers, the cached channels will be continuously physically closed because channelList.size() will always be 10 and equal to getChannelCacheSize().

The fix is to make the comparison a "<=" instead of "<".

That is my interpretation of the channel cache size property. I may have misunderstood the behavior of this property and maybe the above comparison is correct. If so, then the org.springframework.amqp.rabbit.listener.SimpleMessageListenerContainer should be updated to set the channelCacheSize to concurrentConsumers + 1 instead of what is currently doing:

if (cf.getChannelCacheSize() < this.concurrentConsumers) {
cf.setChannelCacheSize(this.concurrentConsumers);
logger.warn("CachingConnectionFactory's channelCacheSize can not be less than the number of concurrentConsumers so it was reset to match: "
+ this.concurrentConsumers);
}
item.summary: CachingConnectionFactory.CachedChannelInvocationHandler channels prematurely closed due to channel cache size comparison being off by 1

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
I don't believe your interpretation is correct.

Within the CachedChannelInvocationHandler the channelList is a reference to the global channelList (either cachedChannelsTransactional or cachedChannelsNotTransactional).

That logic is simply saying (when a channel is closed), if there are less than n (in your case 10) channels already in the list, add it to the list; if it's already at 10 (or more) physically close the channel.

The logic in the SMLC that you referenced is no longer relevant (and should probably be removed).

RabbitUtils.isPhysicalCloseRequired() always returns true for listener container channels, so that unprocessed messages (if any) will be re-queued by the broker (see https://github.com/SpringSource/spring-amqp/pull/73). We can't return these channels to a cache because they might have pending acks. Not caching container channels is not really an issue because they are long-lived. Caching channels is really intended for producers.

Unless you still feel there is an issue, I will either close this issue as invalid or repurpose it for removing that redundant logic in the SLMC.

I'm slightly confused. Then why do i constantly get these warnings in my logs when my channel cache size is set to be the same as the number of concurrent consumers?

2013-08-08 19:06:57.030 WARN  org.springframework.amqp.rabbit.listener.SimpleMessageListenerContainer - Consumer raised exception, processing can restart if the connection factory supports it
 
com.rabbitmq.client.ShutdownSignalException: clean channel shutdown; reason: #method<channel.close>(reply-code=200, reply-text=OK, class-id=0, method-id=0)
 
        at org.springframework.amqp.rabbit.listener.BlockingQueueConsumer.checkShutdown(BlockingQueueConsumer.java:132) ~[spring-rabbit-1.1.3.RELEASE.jar:na]

        at org.springframework.amqp.rabbit.connection.RabbitUtils.closeChannel(RabbitUtils.java:69) ~[spring-rabbit-1.1.3.RELEASE.jar:na]

        ... 6 common frames omitted

That looks to be a different problem...

        at org.springframework.amqp.rabbit.connection.RabbitUtils.closeChannel(RabbitUtils.java:69) ~[spring-rabbit-1.1.3.RELEASE.jar:na]
 
        at org.springframework.amqp.rabbit.connection.ConnectionFactoryUtils.releaseResources(ConnectionFactoryUtils.java:190) ~[spring-rabbit-1.1.3.RELEASE.jar:na]

That implies the transaction commit is closing the listener's channel, which should never happen.

Can you show your container's configuration? Are you doing any RabbitTemplate work on the container's thread?

This is our listener configuration:

        SimpleMessageListenerContainer container = new SimpleMessageListenerContainer();
 
        container.setConnectionFactory(connectionFactory); // CachingConnectionFactory
 
        container.setMessageListener(messageListenerAdapter);
 
        container.setConcurrentConsumers(numConsumers); // 10 in this case
 
        container.setChannelTransacted(true);
 
        container.setTransactionManager(txManager);     // JPA transaction manager 
        container.setTaskExecutor(executor);            // CachedThreadPool executor
 
        container.setQueueNames(getQueueName());
 
        container.setPrefetchCount(RABBIT_PREFETCH_COUNT.get());             // 1
 
        container.setTxSize(RazorQueueConfig.RABBIT_TRANSACTION_SIZE.get()); // 1

We use a RabbitTemplate in the consumer, but it uses a separate connection factory for sending messages onto a separate queue. Maybe this has to do with the other bug (https://jira.springsource.org/browse/AMQP-309) that is pulling up the wrong connection factory to do the sends?

There must be some strange interaction with the JPA Tx Manager...

In your stack trace above, the channel is being closed here in ConnectionFactoryUtils...

	public static void releaseResources(RabbitResourceHolder resourceHolder) {
 
		if (resourceHolder == null || resourceHolder.isSynchronizedWithTransaction()) {
 
			return;
 
		}
 
		RabbitUtils.closeChannel(resourceHolder.getChannel());        <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<
 
		RabbitUtils.closeConnection(resourceHolder.getConnection());
 
	}

This implies resourceHolder.isSynchronizedWithTransaction() is returning false, which shouldn't happen - with the TxManagers I have tested with, the return is always taken here.

It looks like we need to add some protection to not close the consumer's channel there, but I need to understand how it's possible to even get to that line of code.

I am thinking of adding

	public static void closeChannel(Channel channel) {
 
		if (channel == ConnectionFactoryUtils.getConsumerChannel()) {
 
			logger.debug("skipping close of consumer channel");
 
		}
 
		else if (channel != null && channel.isOpen()) {
 
...

to RabbitUtils but I need to understand more about what's happening.

I can't reproduce your issue with a JPA transaction manager; I wonder if you can get a TRACE level log and compare it to this one...

2013-08-08 22:54:18.863 DEBUG [attribution-05] org.springframework.amqp.rabbit.listener.BlockingQueueConsumer - Closing Rabbit Channel: Cached Rabbit Channel: AMQChannel(amqp://guest@10.164.57.122:5672/,10)

I did some further tinkering, and I realized that these errors only appear when I forget to set the appropriate channel size and the org.springframework.amqp.rabbit.listener.SimpleMessageListenerContainer sets the channel size for me:

if (cf.getChannelCacheSize() < this.concurrentConsumers) { 
    cf.setChannelCacheSize(this.concurrentConsumers); 
    logger.warn("CachingConnectionFactory's channelCacheSize can not be less than the number of concurrentConsumers so it was reset to match: " + this.concurrentConsumers); 
}

So maybe there is some weird issue where the setChannelCacheSize is not taking effect in the right place? Very odd, but I can't reproduce when I pass in the current channel cache size. Only when my channel cache size is lower than the number consumers and the warning gets displayed. At this point, it is purely my fault for setting the cache size wrong, but strange that the setChannelCacheSize(...) doesn't fix it.

This is very weird indeed.

I confirmed, in the debugger that the transaction synchronization boolean is getting reset somehow.

I set a breakpoint in releaseResources(); changed the synchronizedWithTransaction boolean to false and I then got your exception. So, we need to figure out how that boolean is getting reset.

I'll try under the circumstances you describe and see if I can figure it out.

Thanks.
I still can't reproduce it, but at least it sounds like you have a work-around for now. I'll look some more tomorrow.

Sorry - I missed your reference to AMQP-309 above.

I noticed in your trace above that the channel is actually being closed by the template, not the consumer itself.

That fix is in the 1.2.0.RELEASE which is available - can you try with that?
Confirmed, upgrading to 1.2.0.RELEASE fixes the issue. This issue can be marked closed. Thanks!
Related to AMQP-309.
